description: From French réprimande, from réprimer (“to repress”).

entries.meaning: A severe, formal or official reproof; reprehension, rebuke, private or public.

verbs.description: reprimand (third-person singular simple present reprimands, present participle reprimanding, simple past and past participle reprimanded)

entries.meaning: To reprove in a formal or official way.
examples: He is struck by Antinous, who is in turn reprimanded by one of the “proud young men” courting Penelope:
